prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NH2 toward W31C
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We propose to search for p-NH2 absorption towards the massive star forming region W31C, . Herschel data have been presented by Persson et al. (2010, 2012) providing excellent coverage of the o-NH2 absorption and emission. the p-NH2 ground state line is best covered from the ground. We have selected other lines to complete the investigation of the nitrogen chemistry (N2D+, NHD2) and of the background source (CO, H 39epsilon). This last setup will also be used to image the continuum emission.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The velocity coverage of the emission/absorption ranges between 50 and 100 km/s. We have therefore selected a broad coverage to detect both the continuum and the multiple absorption component.

We need to maximise the sensitivity and have therefore chosen the most compact configuration. The sources exhibit compact cores and more extended emission. The 5" scale applies to the compact sources which will be used to detect the absorption lines.

The main goal of the project is to perform absorption spectroscopy inthe p-NH2 ground state transition. We aim peak optical depth of 5 - 10% in velocity components with individual line width of a few km/s. We have therefore set the use spectral resolution of 1km/s . To determine the opacities with 10% accuracy, we require a S/N ratio on the continuum of 500. We have chosen bright continuum sources (UCHII) with expected flux densities larger than 10Jy. The required S/N is reached in a short on source integration time (7 min).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NH2 oward G34.2

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NH2 toward W49N
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We propose to search for p-NH2 absorption towards the massive star forming region W49N, . Herschel data have been presented by Persson et al. (2010, 2012) providing excellent coverage of the o-NH2 absorption and emission. the p-NH2 ground state line is best covered from the ground. We have selected other lines to complete the investigation of the nitrogen chemistry (N2D+, NHD2) and of the background source (CO, H 39epsilon). This last setup will also be used to image the continuum emission.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The velocity coverage of the emission/absorption ranges between 50 and 100 km/s. We have therefore selected a broad coverage to detect both the continuum and the multiple absorption component.

We need to maximise the sensitivity and have therefore chosen the most compact configuration. The sources exhibit compact cores and more extended emission. The 5" scale applies to the compact sources which will be used to detect the absorption lines.

The main goal of the project is to perform absorption spectroscopy inthe p-NH2 ground state transition. We aim peak optical depth of 5 - 10% in velocity components with individual line width of a few km/s. We have therefore set the use spectral resolution of 1km/s . prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to observe the para-NH2 ground state transition at 462 GHz toward three massive star forming regions, where ortho-NH2 has been detected with Herschel/HIFI. We will probe both the diffuse ISM along the line of sight and the denser molecular envelope of the molecular cloud hosting these massive star forming regions. The ortho to para ratio in ammonia and its precursor amidogen is a sensitive probe of the presence of para enriched molecular hydrogen. Only ALMA can provide the high S/N required to determine the OPR with the 10% accuracy needed to compare with model predictions and derive the ortho to para ratio of molecular hydrogen.
